overview_of_class: This course develops listening skills and critical vocabulary in order to refine the ways we write and talk about our musical experiences, with particular attention to the kinds of experiences afforded by music from the past. Throughout the quarter, our study of specific musical practices and geographies will be grounded in primary documents from a variety of historical moments, ranging from Ancient Greek culture through 18th-century colonial encounters to the contemporary music landscape. Class time will be spent discussing assigned listening and readings, listening as a group, and practicing oral and written description skills.
name: Introduction to Music
subject: GEN_MUS

overview_of_class: This course provides an introduction to selected musical cultures of the Western world. Proceeding chronologically from the Medieval era through the present day, we will consider music's intellectual and cultural contexts, its creators, and its performance to enhance our understanding of the art form as a cultural practice in specific times and places. Students will develop critical listening skills and build a working vocabulary that is meaningful to the musician and non-musician alike. Preparation of assigned reading and listening will be required of students for each class meeting; additional assignments will include quizzes, exams, essays, and concert attendance.
name: Introduction to Music
subject: GEN_MUS
